awd_titl_txt: IRNC: AMI: The InSight Advanced Performance Measurement System
awd_abstract_narration:
The GLORIAD/InSight program is a global, open-source software development effort to research and experimentally deploy advanced flow-level network measurement technologies at various levels of the research and education (R&E) network eco-system.  The tools developed will enable far-reaching research towards better understanding network utilization, identifying network application performance issues while carefully attending to differing community concerns and requirements regarding data privacy and security. Experimental deployments will showcase actionable analytics and visualizations for network operations, new methods and models of data sharing across the global R&E fabric, and thus a better understood, more performant fabric. 

Through a global, community-focused, open-source development effort, the project extends the current beta version of InSight - the flow-level passive measurement, analysis and visualization system in use on the GLORIAD network. The InSight tools are based on passive network measurement and monitoring by combining the rich detail of comprehensive, non-sampled, bi-directional, multi-model, multi-layer Argus flow-data with modern big-data analytic and visualization tools. A flexible stream-based method of enriching network flow metadata enables broader, customer-defined analytics.  Working closely with interested large-network providers, the project works toward experimentally deploying InSight on links up to 100 Gbps.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Under the IRNC program the team developed InSight2, a web-based software platform for real-time operational network monitoring and retroactive forensic analysis of Argus flow data. InSight2 handles data ingestion and enrichment as well as dashboard based visualization. Users control the type of enrichment that takes place by supplying the databases needed. Users can modify the built-in visualization dashboards or create their own to suit their needs. Users can furthermore develop and add plug-in modules that extend the analytics capabilities. Site-specific visualization dashboards and plug-in modules can readily be shared among users. Available for download from GitHub free of charge, InSight2 may thus serve as a platform for community-based development of network analytics tools.

Implemented to take advantage of modern multi-core and distributed computer architectures, InSight2 enables efficient handling of incoming flow data in real-time without the need for sampling or filtering, even in high throughput environments. InSight2 has been deployed and tested at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville, as well as at Stanford University, the (South) Korea Institute for Science and Technology Information, and Queens University, Canada. As an indication of InSight2's through-put capabilities, the deployment at Stanford University ingests data from a 10Gbps mirror port in one of the School of Engineering?s primary datacenters, connecting over 200 physical servers and approximately 100 virtual machines that handle both administrative applications and research computation. Design and operation of a 100Gbps Argus node was investigated as part of the project but not used to generate InSight2 input.

The project produced two Master's thesis students, who respectively developed the initial version of InSight2 and a plug-in module for detection of significant network events such as packet loss and botnet activities from the flow data. A group of high-school students were introduced to InSight2 and given the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with network flow analysis as well as learn about the underlying Elasticsearch database mechanisms and Kibana dashboard visualizations.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2019
Modified by: Jens Gregor
